ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A deep understanding of Naval history and importance

For the most part this is a class on Naval History and its impacts on world events/conflicts. The readings are fascinating, discussions engaging, and overall a very easy yet stimulating class. Johnson is a great professor and if you have the opportunity to take it with him I definitely would.
I learned a lot about United States Naval History, how we can use lessons from the past to improve our current fleet, as well as how to write papers that analyze events in history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: While the course was very interesting and engaging, it was difficult to balance the readings with other coursework. I enjoyed the seminar nature of the course, as it allowed everyone to participate in discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this class to anyone even slightly interested in U.S. Military/Naval history. This was one of the few classes that I was eager to go to each morning.

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in the imperative and transforming role the Navy played throughout United States history. The instructor does a great job at making the course engaging, even for students outside the NROTC program.
